Award.AwardTitle: EXP: Constructing Multimedia Artifacts Using a Video Repository

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration: This PI team is investigating three aspects of the use of video in education: i) how people learn with video, ii) the role of technology in supporting use of the vast corpora of video generated by decades of research, and iii) how video is used in generative ways to help focus learners on phenomena of interest. The researchers are basing their investigations on the Video Mosaic Collaborative (VMC), a rich collection that includes video from multiple longitudinal studies of children's mathematical reasoning, from urban, working class, and suburban communities in both classroom and informal settings, as children work individually and collaboratively on cognitively challenging math problems. The technological innovation of this project lies in the development of a tool for video selection and annotation, the VMCAnalytic. An analytic is a multimedia object that combines selected portions of video with accompanying text in a sequence of clips to yield a narrative for an intended purpose, which might include such objects as a lesson plan or an exploration of a research question. A critical design decision guides the development of this tool, to capture that information in a standard format that: i) could persist outside the tool, ii) is shareable and reusable in different formats (such as PDF with clickable video links), iii) is readily expanded and enhanced as researcher needs change, and iv) is recognized and treated as an information object in its own right. All developments are open-source, which widens the impact of the project. The project features two research and development cycles. The first cycle examines how college professors use analytics to create learning tasks for their students, and how their perception of what the analytic tool can do aligns with the research team's initial socio-cognitive analysis. The researchers are also studying how learners engage with tasks that were designed (e.g., how they make explicit how learning develops or how teacher moves influence student outcomes), allowing the development of conjectures about how students learn through the multimedia construction tasks. From initial analyses of that data the research team seeks to understand what kinds of supports and scaffolds need development and implementation. The second design cycle then builds on the initial studies and tests some of these supports and scaffolds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project enabled exploratory research on learning opportunities inherent in the construction of multimedia artifacts, specifically through editing and annotating video episodes as a narrative on topics that include learning, teaching, child development, and characteristics of educational environments. It is an outgrowth of prior research featuring longitudinal and cross-sectional studies of students learning mathematics and a large-scale research and development project to create the Video Mosaic Collaborative (VMC) portal (www.videomosaic.org) and design the RUAnalytic tool for constructing annotated video narratives. Prior work was extended by exploring various user perspectives on student engagement with the creation of annotated video narratives, and developing design principles for tasks, supports and scaffolds to create them.

This project advanced development of the RUAnalytic tool, which enables users to select videos, edit and annotate them, and arrange those video events to construct a multimedia narrative. Project experts in digital library systems released a new version of the RUAnalytic tool that improves support for streaming video and provides a three-paned space to search for videos, construct multimedia narratives, and view and comment on the set of shared artifacts in one’s workspace. Workspace is provided to users with a research and/or education agenda (who are screened and agree to follow the VMC code of conduct), to support collaborative research and learning discoveries. An important outcome of this project is the opening of a Community of Practice (COP) portal to extend use of Video Mosaic resources and the RUAnalytic tool for creating VMCAnalytics (multimedia artifacts using the VMC video collection). The VMCAnalytics that users create can undergo peer review and publication with metadata and a DOI for citation at the VMC portal (http://videomosaic.org/analytics/), for long-term impact as a contribution to scholarly discourse in the field. VMCAnalytics represent a new form of scholarly publication where the research data and the analysis are tightly integrated.  They can exist alone or be embedded in other works, such as electronic dissertations, books, and periodicals. There are currently 57 published analytics available for scholarly use at the VMC portal. They have been viewed 2,720 times. 

Researchers conducted exploratory studies to measure student (typically pre-service and in-service teachers) learning as a result of participating in instructional activities in varied course contexts that included mathematics education, educational psychology and developmental psychology. Participants viewed and discussed a selection of video episodes by considering them through lenses defined by the course context and the instructor’s learning goals.  Students then constructed their own narratives by selecting, editing and annotating particular video episodes to make and substantiate their points.  Participants were interviewed after the course to gain a better understanding of the user experience.

Researchers found that constructing VMCAnalytics provides a useful mechanism for students to deepen their understanding of a variety of educational theories, as evidenced through the multimedia artifacts they produce. This was demonstrated in several worthwhile contexts from studies showing benefits of gaining feedback from peers and instructors. Revisiting initial work to revise event content and descriptions yielded evidence of notably improved multimedia products that more clearly articulate theses and claims. Study contexts in which use of VMC videos and RUAnalytic tool were more tightly integrated into the course yielded better outcomes.

Looking across study contexts, researchers identified useful practices for designing interventions using VMC video resources and the RUAnalytic tool. They are: (a) consideration of the learning goals of the context in which the tools are utilized with attention to the needs of the specific learning community, (b) introduction of appropriate task constraints that include limiting the number of video choices and length of video events, (c) providing technical support to the course instructor and students through video tutorials, help documents, and in-person tutorials, and (d) anticipation of technical challenges including internet connectivity and small group work logistics.

The VMC website provides an open portal to view streaming video resources and their metadata, with a total of 331 videos (130+ hours) currently available for use with transcripts for all video and some student work products.  Access to the RUAnalytic tool is available to the education community through the COP portal, which currently has 202 users who are not members of Rutgers University and approximately 250 Rutgers users.  The Rutgers count is approximate, since it is based on RUAnalytic tool use, which extends access to faculty and students to other audiovisual resources hosted on the RUcore platform. There are currently 657 unpublished analytics in private workspaces in the VMC COP. 22,079 visits have been made to the VMC portal since introduction in January 2010, of which 13,942 represent unique users.  There have been 136,900 views of resources at the VMC, of which 115,000 represent video playback and 21,900 downloads of transcripts or student work in PDF format.
